Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation2: My dog becomes vocal in the hallway when people pass near shared doors.
Story: I sat on the couch, glancing at my mom as she quietly folded laundry. I could sense something was off, so I asked, “Is everything okay at home?” She smiled, but her eyes looked tired. I wanted to be there for her, to listen and offer comfort, just like I always tried to do. But then, a sharp bark echoed from the hallway—my dog, again, reacting to footsteps near our shared door. I winced, knowing our neighbor, Mrs. Lee, had already mentioned the noise last week. I felt torn. My parents needed me to be present and supportive, but I also had to keep the peace with our neighbors, making sure my dog didn’t disturb them. The pressure built inside me, the urge to comfort my mom clashing with the responsibility to be a considerate neighbor. I could hear my dog’s barking grow louder, and I felt my heart race, caught between two worlds that both needed me in different ways.
